Title: La Casa del Abuelo
Note: Amazing garlic prawns, cooked right before your eyes!

Title: DeAtún
Note:
A modern tapas bar and restaurant with a focus on tuna, especially the almadraba variety, which is fished off the coast of southern Spain and is very rare and very high quality (85% of the catch goes straight to Japan).
Location: https://g.page/DeAtunPonzano?share
We ordered:
Tuna with wakame sand = €19 “For 6 of them”
Tuna with asparagus = €19 “For 6 of them”
Tuna taco in a shiso leaf = €22 “For 4 of them”
Taco DeAtún con Chimichurri = €6.50
Taquitos DeAtún confitados con huevos de cordoniz y trufa de verano = €6.50

Title: Sala de Despiece
Note:
Modern tapas bar/restaurant where they create imaginative and delicious dishes from fantastic raw ingredients, and with a little bit of a show too. The bar is first-come, first-served - so get early to get in line. Or you can reserve online (http://www.saladedespiece.com/en/rese...) for their seated area alongside the bar (there is a €35 minimum food spend for reservations).
Location: https://goo.gl/maps/X1Cc2s37BE5bqmvZ9
We ordered:
Rolex: €6.50
Chuletón Zenital: €9.00
Beetroot dish which was off menu: €7
Korean Truffle: €14

Title: El Doble
Note:
Old school beer and seafood bar - true Madrid! There are two on the street - we went to the original at this address: https://goo.gl/maps/iEvhg9JCmC6oree79
We ordered:
Media ración of boquerones en vinagre: €7
Ventresca salad with tomatoes: €15

Title: Fide
Note:
Another famous traditional bar, with a particular focus on seafood. There are also two of these in the street, and we went to the original here: https://goo.gl/maps/zqQsGDVJTEUpdHAP6
We ordered:
Zamburiñas (scallops): €12
Pulpo a la gallega (Galician-style octopus): €18

Title: El Anciano Rey de los Vinos
C. del Codo
Note: Want to find those secret nun cookies? Head to Calle Codo (near Plaza de la Villa) and where you see the door with the sign "Venta de Dulces", ring the top bell. Hours are Mon-Fri 0930-1300 then 16.30 - 18.30.

Title: The Hour of the Vermouth,.San Miguel Market
Los Huevos de Lucio
Note: Opposite is a famous restaurant called Casa Lucio. And in that restaurant they’re famous for their huevos estrellados (aka. Huevos rotos or broken eggs). Opposite Los Huevos de Lucio is their tavern, and you can get the same dish there. It’s simple, but it’s delicious!

Title: Taberna Tempranillo
Note: Another classic wine bar that’s been around for a number of years. These guys do an eclectic selection of modern dishes, as well as tostas. And of course great wine by the glass. Also - the wine rack against the back wall is spectacular!

Title: Casa Lucas
Note: Famous on Calle Cava Baja. This place is always packed, but does delicious modern tapas and tostas, and they have an excellent wine list. Don’t worry if you can’t get a table - just squeeze on up at the bar!

Title: Díaz y Larrouy
Note:
The wine bar has been around since 1992 and so is one of the grandfather’s of this street. They have 30-40 wines per glass, and serve delicious tostas. An excellent option for cava by the glass.

- pork thing

Title: Taberna LA CONCHA
Note: I love this spot for a pre-lunch vermouth. They make their own vermouth, and serve it with a few extra ingredients to give it extra kick. They always pair it with a delicious tapa. And their cooked tapas and wine list are also excellent. A great start!

Title: La Castela
Note:
bulltail stew!
scallops tempura thing
rabbit ribs

Title: La catapa
Note:
Seafood (prawn, mussel, octopus thing)
creamy truffle potato croquettes
fresh stingray
